Liquid organic hydrogen carriers have been recently developed as the promising hydrogen storage materials, which exhibit significant advantages in hydrogen storage and utilization compared with the conventional hydrogen storage systems. Highly active and sable Ru/SiO2 catalysts for biphenyl hydrogenation to form bicyclohexyl were synthesized through the strong electrostatic adsorption (SEA) method, and the conventional dry impregnation (DI) method was also considered as comparison. X-ray diffraction, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, transmission electron microscopy, and H2-temperature-programmed reduction characterization techniques were used to investigate the physicochemical properties of the representative catalysts. The results showed that the catalysts synthesized by the SEA method possessed small-sized and well-dispersed Ru nanoparticles (NPs) on the silica support. Especially, 1.5 wt.% Ru/SiO2 catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic activity, stability and reusability, where the initial turnover frequency (TOF) was 11.9 h−1, the conversion of biphenyl was up to 99.9%, and the yield of bicyclohexyl reached 99.9% under the mild conditions (90 °C, 1.0 MPa H2). Further density functional theory (DFT) calculations elucidate that the catalyst with small Ru nanoparticle size exhibits higher catalytic activity for biphenyl hydrogenation. Graphical abstract Ru/SiO2 catalyst synthesized by SEA method exhibited excellent catalytic performance for biphenyl hydrogenation Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ru/SiO2 catalyst Small-sized Ru nanoparticles Biphenyl hydrogenation Bicyclohexyl Hydrogen storage 1 Introduction Presently, clean and sustainable energy sources have been widely sought to alleviate the current problems of energy consumption and environmental pollution [1]. Hydrogen is regarded as an ideal renewable energy source owing to its zero emissions and high energy density [2,3]. However, the difficulties in compression and liquefaction make it extremely challenging to store and transport, along with the huge economic costs and safety issues. Therefore, it is important to develop an economically viable and environmentally friendly hydrogen storage system [4]. Liquid organic hydrogen carriers (LOHCs) have been extensively explored to provide a flexible medium for safe and efficient storage and transportation of hydrogen energy [5–9]. Compared with the conventional hydrogen storage systems, LOHCs have numerous advantages: high hydrogen storage density, reversibility and high selectivity [10]. More important, the promising LOHCs materials are able to fully utilize the existing infrastructure, such as biphenyl (BP), toluene, benzene, naphthalene, diphenylmethane, 2-phenyltoluene, 1-methylnaphthalene, etc. [1,11,12] Among the different liquid chemicals, including cyclic hydrocarbons, formic acid and N-heterocycles, cyclic hydrocarbons are an appropriate candidate considering the cost criteria of hydrogen storage and delivery. Hydrogen is stored in cyclic hydrocarbons and then obtained by catalytic dehydrogenation of the cyclic hydrocarbons. As hydrogen storage materials, cyclic hydrocarbons have the advantages of high boiling point and low toxicity, such as bicyclohexyl (BCH) [13,14], cyclohexane [15,16], methylcyclohexane [17,18], decalin [19,20], perhydro-dibenzyltoluene [21,22]. Particularly, BCH is a very promising candidate for hydrogen storage because of the very low economic cost. It was reported that BCH has the highest catalytic dehydrogenation rate among the cyclic hydrocarbons [23]. Moreover, the generated BP can easily re-absorb hydrogen to from BCH. Therefore, as a hydrogen storage material, BCH is the preferred hydrogenation product with a high gravimetric of 7.3 wt.% and a volumetric hydrogen storage density of 62.8 g L−1. The supported catalysts have attracted the growing attention in the field of catalytic hydrogenation because of its highly metal utilization [24]. Therein, Ru-based catalyst with high activity and selectivity has been proved to be one of the most promising alternatives for the catalytic hydrogenation reactions [25,26]. However, the catalysts prepared by the conventional dry impregnation (DI) method show low catalytic activity and poor stability due to the low atomic utilization and easy aggregation of Ru nanoparticles (NPs) [27]. It has been reported that the strong electrostatic adsorption (SEA) method is greatly beneficial to improve the metal dispersion, which is originated from the support can electrostatically adsorb oppositely charged metal precursor by controlling the final pH value of the solution in the range of the strongest electrostatic interaction [28–31]. According to the dependence of adsorption on the pH value, the adsorption procedure is dominated by the electrostatic interaction rather than chemical reaction or ion exchange [32]. Regalbuto et al. studied the adsorption of a series of metal ammine complexes on the silica support by controlling the pH value with the point of the zero charge (PZC), and reasonably simulated the adsorption process through the revised physical adsorption (RPA) model [33–37]. Therefore, the catalysts synthesized by the SEA method can create highly dispersed metal NPs than those synthesized via the DI method. Besides, the bioreduction method, which was eco-friendly and economic, also has been found to be outstanding for synthesizing well distributed Ru-based catalysts [38,39]. In the present work, we utilized the SEA method to synthesize a series of Ru/SiO2 catalysts with various Ru contents, and compared their catalytic hydrogenation performance with those synthesized by the conventional DI method. According to the detail and systematic characterizations, it was found that the catalysts synthesized by the SEA method exhibited highly dispersed and small-sized Ru NPs over the silica support, while the catalysts synthesized via the DI method possessed larger and unevenly dispersed Ru NPs. Under the same reaction conditions, the catalysts synthesized by the SEA method showed fairly higher catalytic activity for BP hydrogenation than those synthesized via the DI method. After reaction for 80 min, the BCH yield of 1.5 wt.% Ru/SiO2 catalyst reached 99.9%, which is much higher than 1.5 wt.% Ru/SiO2-DI (RuHA) catalyst (43.9%), 1.5 wt.% Ru/SiO2-DI (RuCl3) catalyst (19.8%), and the commercial 5.0 wt.% Ru/C (27.0%). In addition, 1.5 wt.% Ru/SiO2 catalyst showed excellent catalytic hydrogenation activity even after five runs. On the basis of the density functional theory (DFT) calculation results, the higher catalytic activity over the catalysts synthesized by the SEA method can be ascribed to the smaller Ru nanoparticle size, which reduces the adsorption strength of BP and improves the anti-poisoning of catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemical reagents Ruthenium(III) hexaammine chloride ([Ru(NH3)6]Cl3, 98%) precursor, designated as RuHA, was purchased from Alfa Aesar. The reserved RuHA solution was made up at 200 ppm and placed in a volumetric flask. Ruthenium(III) chloride hydrate (RuCl3•xH2O) was obtained from Kunming Sino-Platinum Industry Co., Ltd.. The fumed silica (SiO2) with a specific surface area of 314 m2 g−1 was acquired from Aladdin. NH3•H2O aqueous solution (25.0–28.0 wt.%) was obtained from Luoyang Chemical reagent Factory. Commercial 5.0 wt.% Ru/C catalyst was purchased from Macklin. Biphenyl was available from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.. All reagents are analytical grade (A.R.) and used directly without any further purification. 2.2 Catalyst preparation 2.2.1 Catalyst synthesis by SEA Ru/SiO2 catalysts with different Ru loadings (0.1, 0.5, 1.0, 1.5, 1.6 and 2.4 wt.%) were synthesized by the SEA method. Based on previous studies, the PZC (4.3) of the silica support has been determined [40]. The pH of the metal precursor solution was adjusted to the optimal value (about 11.5) with NH3•H2O aqueous solution, and then added the silica support for adsorption under vigorous stirring at room temperature for 1 h. Subsequently, the precipitate was collected by centrifugation and washed three times with deionized water. The resulting solid was dried overnight in a vacuum drying oven at 60 °C to remove the moisture. Then the solid powder was calcined in the muffle furnace at 120 °C for 4 h. Finally, the sample was reduced in the tube furnace at 400 °C for 2 h under the flow of 10 vol.% H2/N2. 2.2.2 Catalyst synthesis by DI Ru/SiO2 catalysts with two different metal precursors were synthesized by the DI method. The catalyst with precursor [Ru(NH3)6]Cl3 was labeled as 1.5 wt.% Ru/SiO2-DI (RuHA), and the catalyst with precursor RuCl3•xH2O was simplified as 1.5 wt.% Ru/SiO2-DI (RuCl3). The water absorption capacity of the employed silica support was determined as 2.4 mL g−1. Typically, the stoichiometric metal precursor solution was diluted to 2.4 mL with deionized water. The silica support (1.0 g) was then added into the abovementioned solution under vigorous stirring. The obtained samples were dried, calcined and reduced using the same procedure with the catalysts synthesized by the SEA method. 2.3 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the employed samples were recorded on a Bruker D8 diffractometer operated at 40 kV and 40 mA with Cu Kα radiation source (λ = 0.15418 nm) in the 2θ range of 10–80° at a scanning speed of 0.03 ° s−1. Ru concentrations in the specimens were measured on the inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) with ICPE-9820 instrument. The low-temperature N2 adsorption-desorption experiments were collected on a Micromeritics ASAP 2420 instrument. The relative pressure condition for measuring pore volume was 0.99. About 100 mg of the sample was used for adsorption analysis after pretreatment at 150 °C for 3 h under vacuum conditions. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was performed on a PHI Quantera SXM spectrometer with Al Kα radiation (hν = 1486.6 eV) as the excitation source under ultrahigh vacuum conditions. The pressure criteria were 10−9 Torr. In the deconvolution process, a Shirley background was subtracted before the peak fitting with a symmetric Gauss-Lorentz sum function being performed. In the data fitting process, the Ru 3d doublet separation value was set to 4.2 eV. The Ru 3d5/2 and Ru 3d3/2 doublet had a 3:2 peak area ratio and equal FWHM. The binding energies were referred to the C 1s line at 284.8 eV from the adventitious carbon. All the catalysts were pretreated by reduction in H2/Ar atmosphere. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) measurements were made on a FEI Tecnai G2 F20 electron microscope operated at 200 kV. Several milligrams of catalysts were dispersed in anhydrous ethanol for 20 min ultrasonic treatment, and then the suspension was dispersed onto a carbon-film-coated copper grid. All metal NPs were assumed to be spherical and the diameters of the metal NPs were measured. Particle size distribution histograms were generated by randomly measuring at least 100 particles. H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was carried out on the Quantachrome Autosorb-IQ gas adsorption analyzer equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). About 50 mg of sample was placed at the center of the U-shaped tube, which was treated under an Ar flow (40 mL min−1) at 200 °C for 40 min and cooled down to 40 °C. Subsequently, the mixture flow of 10 vol.% H2/Ar (40 mL min−1) was switched into the tube for 15 min. The curve of H2 consumption was obtained at a temperature ramp of 10 °C min−1 from 40 to 400 °C. The dispersion of metallic Ru was determined by CO pulse chemisorption. About 50 mg of sample was flowed with He for 40 min at 140 °C and then cooled to 50 °C. Pure CO pulses were injected until the eluted peak did not change in intensity. The dispersion of Ru was calculated on the basis of the CO uptake with the assumption of Ru:CO stoichiometry of 2:1 [26,41]. The in-situ Fourier-transformed infrared (FT-IR) spectra of CO adsorption on the samples were measured to research the surface structure of supported metal catalysts. The samples were reduced at 400 °C for 60 min under 10 vol.% H2/N2 and then cooled to 25 °C under evacuation. The background spectrum was collected in the flowing He at 25 °C and the sample was exposed to 1% CO/He flow to make it saturated. The FT-IR spectra were collected at different temperatures to monitor the desorption behavior of the adsorbed CO. 2.4 Catalyst testing The reaction of BP hydrogenation was performed in a 100 mL high pressure reactor system (YZQR-100) equipped with an electronic temperature controller, a mechanical stirrer, and a tube for the sampling of the liquid phase products. In a typical experiment, after introducing 0.13 g of catalyst, 1.54 g of BP, and 45 mL of isopropanol, the autoclave was sealed completely and purged with H2 for three times. The reaction conditions were temperature of 90 °C, H2 pressure of 1.0 MPa, and stirring speed of 500 rpm. After the reaction test was completed for the desired time, the reaction system was cooled to room temperature. The obtained products via centrifugation were analyzed online by a SHIMADZU Gas Chromatograph Mass Spectrometer (GCMS-QP2010 SE) with an Auto Injector (SHIMADZU AOC-20i), which was equipped with an SH-RXI-5SIL MS chromatographic column (30 m, 0.25 mm i.d., stationary phase thickness of 0.25 μm) and a flame ionization detector (FID). The initial temperature of the oven was set at 70 °C and increased to 280 °C at the heating rate of 20 °C min−1. At the same time, the temperatures of the injector and FID were set to 260 °C and 270 °C, respectively. The analysis method of BP hydrogenation was area normalization method based on the single hydrogenation product. In a typical recycling experiment, the mixture was centrifuged at 8000 rpm to get the solid catalyst after one reaction cycle (80 min), which was washed with isopropanol for three times and dried overnight at 60 °C for the next use directly. To compare the intrinsic catalytic activity of BP, the TOF of BP was calculated as: T O F = r 0 × M R u d i s p e r s i o n × W where M R u is the molar mass of Ru, W is the metallic loading of Ru on the catalyst, and the Ru dispersion is determined by CO pulse chemisorption. The weight-specific activity ( r 0 ) is the amount of BP converted per gram minute of the catalyst at zero reaction time ( t 0 ). Specifically, the experimental BP content-reaction time curve is fitted by a polynomial equation with respect to t, which is then differentiated, and the r 0 is acquired by replacing t with zero. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physicochemical properties Table 1 lists the compositional and textural properties of the silica support and various Ru/SiO2 catalysts. The actual metal loading of the catalyst was determined by ICP-AES. Notably, the specific surface areas of the SiO2 supported catalysts are lower than that of the silica support, while their pore volumes and pore diameter show the inverse trend. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms (Fig. S1) of the representative samples belong to type Ⅳ with H3 hysteresis loop [26], which illustrate their mesoporous structure. It is obviously found that all the different Ru/SiO2 catalysts have similar pore volume and pore diameter. Additionally, the specific surface area of 1.5 wt.% Ru/SiO2 catalyst is 218.3 m2 g−1, which is much lower than that of 1.5 wt.% Ru/SiO2-DI (RuHA) catalyst (245.0 m2 g−1) and 1.5 wt.% Ru/SiO2-DI (RuCl3) catalyst (256.4 m2 g−1) with the same metal loading. This may be due to the higher dispersion of Ru NPs on the surface of 1.5 wt.% Ru/SiO2 catalyst. Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of the silica support and various catalysts. The broad peak at 2θ of 22° is attributed to amorphous silica (JCPDS Card No. 89–3433), corresponding to the diffraction of the (111) crystal plane. The characteristic peaks of metallic Ru are not detected, which can be ascribed to the small size of the highly dispersed Ru NPs below the detection limit of the XRD technique [42]. Additionally, after Ru loading, the patterns of the silica support are well retained, showing that the mild preparation conditions do not change the crystallographic phases of the silica support. For the 1.5 wt.% Ru/SiO2-DI (RuHA) catalyst, the broad peak at 2θ of 22.0° belongs to the SiO2(101), and the weak diffraction peak at 2θ of 44.0° is pertain to Ru(101), which indicates that some Ru NPs are aggregated on the surface of the catalyst. For the 1.5 wt.% Ru/SiO2-DI (RuCl3) catalyst, the broad peak at 2θ of 21.5° is attached to the SiO2(111) and the diffraction peak of metallic Ru is also not detected. According to the TEM and HAADF-STEM images in Fig. 2 , the catalysts synthesized by the SEA method exhibit small and homogeneous Ru NPs over the silica support. Furthermore, the statistical analysis shows a very narrow particle size distribution of Ru NPs varied from 0.2 nm to 1.8 nm and the average Ru nanoparticle sizes are only about 0.9 nm. Meanwhile, the particle size distribution histograms of Ru NPs match well to the normal distribution curve. The obtained results confirm that the homogenously dispersed Ru NPs on the silica support, which are consistent with the XRD results. In addition, the images indicate that the average Ru nanoparticle sizes do not change much with increasing metal loading from 0.1 to 2.4 wt.%. The Ru nanoparticle sizes of 1.5 wt.% Ru/SiO2-DI (RuHA) catalyst and 1.5 wt.% Ru/SiO2-DI (RuCl3) catalyst are slightly higher, where the size distributions are 1.0–7.0 nm and 1.0–6.0 nm, and the average particle sizes are 3.21 nm and 3.16 nm, respectively. In addition, no Ru NPs, where the particle sizes are less than 1 nm, are observed in the TEM images. Therefore, the catalysts synthesized by the DI method produce larger and poorly dispersed Ru NPs over the silica support than those synthesized by the SEA method. The Ru 3d5/2 peak is selected to identify the chemical states of Ru species owing to the serious overlapping of C 1s and Ru 3d3/2 peaks. The peak at 284.8 eV is attributed to C 1s of carbonaceous contamination, and employed as a reference for the binging energy correction. Fig. 3 shows that, the C 1s spectra also present two peaks at 286.5 eV and 288.8 eV, which are ascribed to carbonaceous species associated with oxygen and/or hydrogen [43,44]. The square root of reduced x2 of the eight catalysts from top to bottom are 0.49, 0.33, 0.64, 0.99, 0.97, 0.68, 0.49, and 1.43 respectively. For all the catalysts, the Ru 3d5/2 peaks position at 280.7–281.7 eV are attributed to the metallic Ru0 and might be accompanied by partially oxidized Ru species [45]. The binding energies of Ru 3d5/2 peaks of 1.5 wt.% Ru/SiO2-DI (RuHA) catalyst and 1.5 wt.% Ru/SiO2-DI (RuCl3) catalyst are located at 280.7 eV and 280.8 eV. It is noteworthy that the binding energies of Ru 3d5/2 peaks of catalysts synthesized by the SEA method are much higher than those synthesized via the DI method, which are also higher than the bulk Ru (279.6–280.2 eV) in the literature [46]. Such high binding energy might be related to the finely dispersed metallic Ru NPs, which probably also results from the strong metal-support interaction between the Ru NPs and the silica support [47]. Therefore, the XPS results are generally in agreement with the XRD and TEM measurements, confirming the formation of highly dispersed Ru NPs on the silica support. Two distinct H2-TPR peaks at 262–275 °C and 343–367 °C are observed (Fig. 4 a) on the catalysts synthesized by the SEA method, which are ascribed to the reduction of different chemical states of RuOx species over the silica support [42]. The peaks at low temperature correspond to the reduction of RuO2 oxide to metallic Ru0, while the peaks at high temperature are ascribed to the reduction of Ru3+ ions to metallic Ru0. Nevertheless, only one peak appears in the TPR patterns for catalysts synthesized by the DI method, where the H2-TPR peaks of 1.5 wt.% Ru/SiO2-DI (RuHA) catalyst and 1.5 wt.% Ru/SiO2-DI (RuCl3) catalyst are located at 252 and 265 °C, respectively. According to the TPR profiles, a common feature is that the samples synthesized by the DI method always present sharp and narrow H2-TPR peaks, whereas the samples synthesized by the SEA method present much larger reduction peak areas, indicating that the samples synthesized by the SEA method have more Ru oxides or higher extent of oxidation. The samples synthesized by the SEA method have higher reduction temperature, which is due to the existence of strong metal-support interaction between the Ru NPs and the silica support. As illustrated in Fig. 4b, the bands locating at 2082–2001 cm−1 can be assigned to linearly bonded CO on Ru0 atoms, and the bands at 1850–1806 cm−1 can be ascribed to bridge bonded CO on two neighboring Ru atoms [48–50]. The presence of linearly bonded CO might be due to the relatively independent and uniform dispersion of Ru NPs on the surface of the silica support. No CO adsorption peak of 0.1 wt.% Ru/SiO2 catalyst is observed, which may be due to its low metal loading. Compared with the 1.5 wt.% Ru/SiO2-DI (RuHA) catalyst, a red shift of the linear adsorption peak of the catalysts synthesized by the SEA method is clearly observed. Furthermore, the peak area and signal strength of the catalysts synthesized by the SEA method are much higher than that of 1.5 wt.% Ru/SiO2-DI (RuHA) catalyst, which might be because the catalysts synthesized by the SEA method have smaller Ru NPs and stronger metal-support interaction, resulting in the stronger CO adsorption strength. 3.2 Catalytic performance The effects of different reaction conditions on the performance over 1.5 wt.% Ru/SiO2 catalyst for BP hydrogenation reaction are presented in Fig. 5 . The conversion of BP linearly increases from 23.3% to 99.9% with the reaction time increasing from 10 to 80 min (Fig. 5a). Nevertheless, the selectivity of BCH increases slowly from 24.8% at 10 min to 35.3% at 60 min, but increases rapidly to 99.9% at 80 min. In the terms of 1.5 wt.% Ru/SiO2-DI (RuHA) catalyst (Fig. S2), when the reaction time reaches 80 min, the conversion of BP is 99.9%, but the selectivity of BCH is only 45.6%. As seen in Fig. 5b, the BP conversion increases from 73.6% to 99.9% and the BCH selectivity increases from 45.7% to 99.9% accordingly, as the temperature raises from 50 °C to 90 °C. As shown in Fig. 5c, when the hydrogen pressure raises from 0.5 MPa to 1.0 MPa, the BP conversion and the BCH selectivity increase from 70.5% to 99.9% and 28.7% to 99.9%, respectively. The results can be ascribed to the fact that the surface hydrogen content can increase with hydrogen pressure increasing, leading to the higher catalyst activity [51]. From Fig. 5d, when the Ru/BP mole ratio increases from 0.0005 to 0.0020, the conversion of BP increases from 63.7% to 99.9%, and the selectivity of BCH increases from 32.2% to 99.9%. Therefore, the obtained results suggest that the optimal reaction conditions for BP hydrogenation are reaction time of 80 min, reaction temperature of 90 °C, hydrogen pressure of 1.0 MPa, and Ru/BP mole ratio of 0.0020. In addition, for this kind of complete hydrogenation, improving the reaction conditions can improve the catalytic performance of the reaction. Table 2 presents the catalytic activities performance of BP hydrogenation for the catalysts synthesized by the SEA and DI methods. The TOF values of BP over the catalysts are calculated based on the r0 and dispersion data. As can be seen from Fig. 6 , the relation between metal loading and hydrogenation activity is studied. It should be pointed out that the assumption of Ru:CO stoichiometry of 2:1 can result in the deviation for calculating the Ru dispersion, because both of linearly adsorbed and bridge bonded CO molecules exist according to the In-situ FTIR spectra of CO adsorption. On the other hand, the results of estimated Ru dispersion coincide with the trend of TEM results. So, the CO probe is appropriate to semi-quantitatively compare the Ru dispersion. The catalytic activity of the catalysts synthesized by the SEA method increases with the increase of metal loading. The 0.1 wt.% Ru/SiO2 catalyst shows the highest TOF of 202.6 h−1, but the conversion of BP and the selectivity of BCH are only 46.7% and 29.8%, respectively. Among all the catalysts, the TOF value of the 0.1 wt.% Ru/SiO2 catalyst is extremely high. This fact may be ascribed to that some smaller Ru NPs than 0.2 nm maybe not be taken into account, because they are too small to be identified. So, there may be some atomically dispersed Ru species in the 0.1 wt.% Ru/SiO2 catalyst. The 1.5 wt.% Ru/SiO2 catalyst shows higher catalytic activity, where the conversion of BP and the selectivity of BCH are as high as 99.9%, although its TOF decreases to 11.4 h−1. Furthermore, the TOF of 1.6 wt.% Ru/SiO2 catalyst and 2.4 wt.% Ru/SiO2 catalyst significantly decrease to 8.8 h−1 and 5.1 h−1, respectively. Compared with the 1.5 wt.% Ru/SiO2 catalyst, the 1.5 wt.% Ru/SiO2-DI (RuHA) catalyst and the 1.5 wt.% Ru/SiO2-DI (RuCl3) catalyst show lower BCH yield, which are 43.9% and 19.8%, respectively. It should be pointed out that the activity of 1.5 wt.% Ru/SiO2-DI (RuHA) catalyst is higher than of 1.5 wt.% Ru/SiO2-DI (RuCl3) catalyst, although the average Ru NPs size in the former is larger than that in the latter. This fact can be ascribed to the larger amount of smaller Ru NPs in the former. The ratio of Ru NPs in 1.5 wt.% Ru/SiO2-DI (RuHA) catalyst below 3.0 nm is 63.0%, which is larger than that in 1.5 wt.% Ru/SiO2-DI (RuCl3) catalyst (40.4%). The results suggest that the catalytic hydrogenation ability of catalysts with highly dispersed Ru NPs is stronger. The 5.0 wt.% Ru/C-(Commercial) catalyst exhibits the low catalytic activity, where the conversion of BP and the selectivity of BCH are 70.6% and 38.2%, respectively. As a consequence, the catalysts synthesized by the SEA method exhibit significant advantages in catalytic activity and atomic utilization over those synthesized by the DI method. 3.3 DFT calculations The DFT calculations were calculated to further investigate the different performance of the employed Ru/SiO2 catalysts on BP hydrogenation. Due to the much larger size of Ru NPs on Ru/SiO2 (DI) and strong XRD signal of Ru(101), the Ru(101) surface was used. Ru30 nanoparticle (~0.9 nm in diameter) supported on SiO2(111) surface was used as the model of Ru/SiO2 (SEA), and the bare Ru30 nanoparticle was also taken into account to study the effect of SiO2 support. The adsorption energies of BP, cyclohexylbenzene (CHB) and H on Ru(101), Ru30 and Ru30/SiO2(111) surfaces are summarized in Fig. 7 a. It is found that the adsorption energy of BP on Ru(101) is 4.97 eV, which is so strong that it can easily lead to the catalyst poisoning. However, it significantly decreases to 3.20 eV on Ru30 and 2.72 eV on Ru30/SiO2(111), respectively, which is mainly ascribed to the decreased adsorption sites of small Ru NPs in the light of their different adsorption geometric structures (Fig. 7 and Fig. S3). The weakened interaction is beneficial for improving the catalytic activity [52–55]. The adsorption energy of CHB on Ru(101) is 3.39 eV, which is also larger than those on Ru30 (2.17 eV) and Ru30/SiO2(111) (2.29 eV), suggesting CHB is easier to desorb on Ru30 and Ru30/SiO2(111) than that on Ru(101). Compared with Ru30 and Ru30/SiO2(111), the catalytic activity of CHB hydrogenation on Ru(101) is significantly suppressed due to its over high adsorption energy, which coincides with experimental results very well. As shown in Fig. 5a, the conversion of BP linearly increases to 70.6% when the reaction time reaches 60 min, but the selectivity of BCH slowly increases to 35.3%, because the intermediate CHB is desorbed before further hydrogenation due to the higher adsorption energy of BP. When most of BP transforms into CHB, it adsorbs again and further hydrogenates to BCH quickly at the last 20 min. However, the selectivity of BCH slowly increases to 45.6% at the last 20 min for the 1.5 wt.% Ru/SiO2-DI (RuHA) (Fig. S2), although the conversion of BP reaches 99.9%. It is found that the hydrogen adsorption on the Ru30 nanocluster is slightly strengthened by 0.05 eV than that on Ru(101) surface, but it decreases by 0.13 eV after supported on SiO2 due to the strong metal-support interaction, which was also confirmed by the charge transfer from Ru30 nanocluster to SiO2 (Fig. S4). 3.4 Reusability study The recycling ability of 1.5 wt.% Ru/SiO2 catalyst for BP hydrogenation is shown in Fig. 8 . When the reaction conditions of the second cycle reaction are 90 °C, 1.0 MPa, and 80 min (Fig. S5), the conversion of BP is 99.2%, while the selectivity of BCH is only 53.1%. A new diffraction peak at 2θ of 44.1° is observed (Fig. S7), which is attached to the Ru(101). According to the TEM characterization result (Fig. S8), the size of Ru NPs shows the obvious growth after one recycle, where the average particle size increases from 0.91 nm to 1.63 nm. The square root of reduced x2 of the catalyst in Fig. S9 is 0.46. Compared with the fresh 1.5 wt.% Ru/SiO2 catalyst, the Ru 3d5/2 peak of the used catalyst shifts to 280.9 eV in the direction of low binding energy, which might be due to the reduction of partially oxidized Ru species. The results elucidate that the small Ru NPs size has higher hydrogenation activity and particle agglomeration leads to the deactivation of the catalyst. However, the performance of 1.5 wt.% Ru/SiO2 catalyst recovers by increasing the hydrogen pressure to 2.0 MPa, and it shows excellent reusability after five recycles. The conversion of BP and the selectivity of BCH remain almost unchanged. As shown in Fig. S6, the conversion of BP decreases from 98.8% to 53.9% and the selectivity of BCH decreases from 44.5% to 15.2% over 1.5 wt.% Ru/SiO2-DI (RuHA) catalyst after four recycles. Therefore, under the same reaction conditions, the catalysts synthesized by the SEA method have higher stability than those synthesized via the DI method. Combined with the results of DFT calculation, the increase of Ru nanoparticle size can enhance the adsorption of BP and CHB, which accordingly leads to decrease in the catalytic activity of BP hydrogenation. 4 Conclusions In summary, a series of Ru/SiO2 catalysts have been successfully synthesized using the SEA method, and their physicochemical properties and catalytic performance for biphenyl hydrogenation have been investigated in detail. XRD and TEM characterization results indicate that the Ru NPs are well dispersed on the silica support. It is demonstrated that the 1.5 wt.% Ru/SiO2 catalyst shows exceedingly high catalytic performance, which exhibits high activity, selectivity, and stability upon the repetitive recycling. According to the DFT calculations, the adsorption properties of BP and CHB strongly depend on Ru nanoparticle size, and their adsorption strength on smaller Ru nanoparticles is decreased, resulting the enhanced anti-poisoning ability and higher catalytic activity. coredata.dc:description: Liquid organic hydrogen carriers have been recently developed as the promising hydrogen storage materials, which exhibit significant advantages in hydrogen storage and utilization compared with the conventional hydrogen storage systems. Highly active and sable Ru/SiO2 catalysts for biphenyl hydrogenation to form bicyclohexyl were synthesized through the strong electrostatic adsorption (SEA) method, and the conventional dry impregnation (DI) method was also considered as comparison. X-ray diffraction, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, transmission electron microscopy, and H2-temperature-programmed reduction characterization techniques were used to investigate the physicochemical properties of the representative catalysts. The results showed that the catalysts synthesized by the SEA method possessed small-sized and well-dispersed Ru nanoparticles (NPs) on the silica support. Especially, 1.5 wt.% Ru/SiO2 catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic activity, stability and reusability, where the initial turnover frequency (TOF) was 11.9 h−1, the conversion of biphenyl was up to 99.9%, and the yield of bicyclohexyl reached 99.9% under the mild conditions (90 °C, 1.0 MPa H2). Further density functional theory (DFT) calculations elucidate that the catalyst with small Ru nanoparticle size exhibits higher catalytic activity for biphenyl hydrogenation.
coredata.dc:title: Highly dispersed and ultra-small Ru nanoparticles deposited on silica support as highly active and stable catalyst for biphenyl hydrogenation
